rooms.title: Starting the adventure
rooms.description: There are many a heroes in history but none so clever as Odysseus. Let us regale a tale about this great hero's travels home and the perilous journey he traversed, and this time you will act as him and lead his crew.

rooms.title: Hello Odysseus, Goodbye Troy
rooms.description:
After a long and grueling war and heavy losses on both sides, the Trojan war has finally concluded, the Achaeans have prevailed with rewards plentiful.

All soldiers and men have started their journey home, one such man called Odysseus, namely you, is already making the long voyage home with his men, across the ocean to Ithaca.

Along the way, your crew spots the city of Ismarus belonging to the Cicones, an enemy of the Achaeans. Your crew wishes to raid the city and take its riches and women.

You too are wanting to raid it, believing the gods have blessed you and your exploits, but a part of you believing this is too prideful does not wish to take part, what shall you do?

options.description: Raid Ismarus, what could go wrong?
Let's not raid, something is off.

rooms.title: Raid Ismarus, city of the Cicones
rooms.description:
You and your warriors are off to raid the city, and raid it you did. By nightfall you have completely conquered the city, looted its riches and women.

However, the bit of apprehension earlier is slowly firing off warning signals in your brain. However, a priestess of Apollo, Maroni, that you protected during the raid earlier has offered a place to stay the night and something else (wink wink) as well, do you stay?

rooms.title: Don't raid Ismarus
rooms.description:
Although it might seem your fears might have gotten the best of you, you decide to not raid the city and instead continue along the way to Ithaca. However, a rumbling beneath the ocean floor occurs with tremors that reach your ship and all of the sudden a massive wave appears.

It carries your men adn your ships to parts unknown, your journey has been diverted.

rooms.title: The isle of the Lotus-eaters
rooms.description:
The strange phenomenon has subsided, and you find yourself on a strange, unknown land. On this land you meet the natives and while hostile to them at first, you find them to be a docile, looney sort of people and you dub them the Lotus-eaters as they seem to only consume the fruit of the lotuses found on the island.

The Lotus-eaters offer you the fruit of the lotus and while some of your crew readily accept and consume the fruit, some of your crew, including you, are apprehensive and are unsure whether to eat it, what will you do?

options.description: Eat the fruit, the natives might be loopy but what could possibly go wrong?
Don't eat the fruit, but take some with you instead.

rooms.title: Eat the fruit
rooms.description:
Words cannot describe how dumb this decision was and you speedily scarf the fruit down. As the fruit's effects take hold, you slowly start to forget everything about 

Ith- Ithmaca? 
Itharus? 
Pepelope? 
Whatever those things are, they don't matter, all you want to do is consume that sweet, sweet fruit.

DEAD END

rooms.title: Don't eat the fruit
rooms.description:
Taking the sensible (read: coward) option you decide to not eat the fruit. Whereas those who did, namely your crew, quickly fall under the effects of the fruit, thinking only of consuming the fruit and no longer remembering home. You and the remaining crew who have common sense forcefully drag the fruit-fed morons back to the ship and away from the island, locking them until they come back to their senses. 

With that misadventure over you continue your voyage back to Ithaca.

rooms.title: Take some fruit and leave
rooms.description:
When offered the fruits you decide to instead stash them away for future use, perhaps they'll come in handy?

Regardless, the ones who ate the fruits instead, namely your crew, quickly fall under the effects of the fruit, thinking only of consuming the fruit and no longer remembering home. You and the remaining crew who have common sense forcefully drag the fruit-fed morons back to the ship and away from the island, locking them until they come back to their senses.

With that misadventure over you continue your voyage back to Ithaca.

rooms.title: Isle be the one to decide that
rooms.description:
As you sail through the murky waters in the night, you spot an island full of wild goats, you must be nearby the land of the Cyclopses, an uncivilized race of large imposing humanoid creatures with only a singular eye. You and your crew decide to rest and partake in the wild meat, taking a break from the unrelenting sea.

The land you currently are on is lush and fertile, filled with serene forests and untilled land, brimmed with natural harbors and fresh harbors. You wonder if this is a place that can be settled upon, so filled curiosity you ponder the idea of visiting the Cyclopian neighbors, to see if they are of the civilized sort to allow this deed, or of hostile intentions.

With the gods on your side, there is no possible way this encounter will be anything less than fortunate, so do you take the opportunity?

options.description: That's a dumb idea, back to the ships

rooms.title: Eye spy a Cyclops
rooms.description:
Feeling luck is on your side, you and your crew take some provisions (after some badgering) head into the Cyclops's lair. However, when you enter it seems that the resident is not there at the moment, probably out sheparding his flock, so your crew decides to help themselves to the Cyclops's own provisions. Stocked with boatloads of cheese (10/10 flavor), the crew gorges upon the dairy while not forgetting to sacrifice some while you wait for your soon to be host to come back.

As Helios finishes pulling his chariot and Selene begins her route, the Cyclops appears, closes the entrance with a massive boulder, and like any good host does asks his guests (who totally didn't intrude upon his domain) who they are and how they came. You supplicant his questions with non answers, you yourself also not trusting him, and ask for his hospitality. In response the Cyclops politely helps himself to two of your crewmates.

You and your crewmates are wracked with fear, you could have never enivisioned youself in this situation, how could this behemoth of a monster (who is part of a race known to be uncivilized) kill your crewmates after you rudely barged into to his home, ate his food supply, and demanded hosptiality. 100% unbelievable that this could happen, truly.

But anyways, the situation is dire, although the Cyclops has fallen asleep, if your men attempt to slay the giant they have no way of moving the massive boulder blocking the entrance. It also a matter of time before the giant awakens and begins his feast again. Is there anything to get you out of this situations, perhaps an item or two?

options.description: Perhaps a bit of Apollonian wine will do the trick?
Lotus fruit is good for the body, not for Cyclopses though
You have nothing up your sleave, uh oh

rooms.title: Back to Ithaca, that was easy
rooms.description:
You decided not the visit the Cyclopses that would totally not eat you. Although this was a good retreat, in your heart you knew that was a lame, uncool idea, your crewmates even said that too (can they read your mind????). You and your crew head back to the ships and continue on you journey. said joruney was unbelievably easy from then on and you reach Ithaca at breakneck speeds.

Wow, good job lame-o.

Secret Good End 1

rooms.title: Wine for you and, well, only you
rooms.description:
Remembering you brought the Apollonian wine with you, the one strong enough to knock out any being for quite a while, you quickly devise a plan to escape with your men. You all grab the club the Cyclops uses and begin fashioning it into a makeshift lance and, using the fire you made, char and harden the point. When the behemoth returns at dusk, you immediately spring into action and entice the arrogant giant into drinking the wine which he readily gulps down along with two more of your men. While doing so, he asks you one more question, your name. You wiley respond that you are outis, Nobody.

One second he's awake and the next he's out cold, at that moment you and your men hoist the lance above the giant head and plung into his only eye. He awakes screaming and clutches in his head in pain, seeking to find the perpetrators but only to find that darkness has enveloped the world. He cries for help and the other Cyclopses arrive after a moment, asking the Cyclops, who you now know to be Polyphemus, what happened. All he can do is say that "Nobody is killing him, Nobody attacked me.". That other Cyclopses scoff and laugh at his response, deeming him have lost his sanity and leave without recuperation.

The next morning when Polyphemus lets his herd out, you and your men slip away, underneath the bellies of the herd and quickly head back to the ship. The moment you begin to sail out you, using 100% of your brain, begin to taunt the giant of your escape and in return the Cyclops uses the sound of your voice to throw giant boulders to your location, but you barely dodge them. Then using 1000% of your brain, you taunt him by saying that not only that you aren't "Nobody", but in fact you are Odysseus. Hearing your name, he immediately begins to pray to his father, Poseidon, for your downfall or, at the very least, that you journey be long and arduous, full of troubles. With that, the god of the sea is now your enemy on your ocean journey.

Good Job!

rooms.title: Lotus fruit is an essential part of a Cyclops's diet
rooms.description:
While thinking of a plan, you spot the Lotus fruit that you had brought with you and quickly devise a plan on the spot. When the Cyclops returns at dusk, you immediately entice him to eat the fruit, saying that it is more succulent than the nectar of the gods. Believing himself to be higher than the gods, the Cyclops readily devours the fruit along with two of your crewmates.

The moment he finishes eating the fruit, he immediately appears to be in a trance, a lotus fruit stupor. He immediately begins asking, pleading for more fruit, forgetting who holds the cards in this situation. You tell him that he can find more fruit beyond the cavern walls and across the ocean. He immediately rushes to open the cave and head out to finding more fruit, you and your men following behind. He quickly leaps into the ocean and begins swimming towards the direction you pointed him to and you and your men quickly regroup with your remaining crew and board your ships.

You begin to sail out while keeping the swimming Cyclops in your view, but eventually that swimming turns to flailing once the Cyclops grows tired and when you sense he is about to start drowning you begin to taunt him with laden insults. It seems your words have shaken him out of that stupor as hes begins to hurl back insults as his final words, with your only response being that it was you, Odysseus, that led to his downfall. With his final breath, he prays to his father, Poseidon, for your downfall or, at the very least, that you journey be long and arduous, full of troubles. With those last breaths, he sinks beneath the ocean, into his father domain.With that, the god of the sea is now your enemy on your ocean journey.

Good Job!

rooms.title: Maybe some wine or fruit would have done the trick
rooms.description:
You try to come up with a plan to escape, but without any items that could leave the Cyclops vunerable you are out of any options. In one last final act of anger, you and your men attack the Cyclops and manage to kill the sleeping behemoth, without casualties. However, with no way out you and your men are now trapped with no way out and although you hear your men that stayed behind yelling about your status and trying to get in, theres nothing they can do and you are now trapped to a long, painful death of starvation or dehydration with what meager resources you or the giant had.

Maybe checking the cave was a bad idea?

DEAD END

rooms.title: The wind will guide you
rooms.description:
Continuing out from your fateful encounter with the Cyclops, you head toward the Aeolian island where Aeolus, keeper of the winds, lived. There he granted you hospitality and allowed you to stay for however long you wanted which you gladly accepted. You stayed for over a month, granting Aeolus great joy while you regaled him with stories of your adventures. Eventually when it was time to leave, you told him you must go which he gladly obliged. He even made you an ox-hide sack to contain the roaring winds which would beset your journey and told you to keep them safe and secure so they would not interfere with your journey back to Ithaca. 

And interfere they did that, for more than a week the winds guided you back to Ithaca, you could even see the land in sight, however some of your men have been wanting to see what is in side your bag, and you bet some of them are plotting to open it, what will you do?

options.description: Open the bag and inhale it (why?)
Don't allow them to open the bag, you have some wine and fruit on you don't you?
There's nothing you can do, the bag is opened

rooms.title: That wasn't a great idea also KABOOOOOM
rooms.description:
Deciding to take the matters in your own hands, the only way possibly to prevent your men from openning the bag is for you yourself to open it and inhale it (????????????).

While I could describe what happened to you after you inhaled the roaring winds, I won't. But I will say it was rather gruesome and your ship probably needs a deep cleaning after what happened.

DEAD END

rooms.title: Fruit and wine make perfect distractions when they're basically drugs
rooms.description:
You decide to take matters in to your own hands and with the Apollonian wine and lotus fruit you've kept safe just in case, you sneak the combination into the next crew meal and just as you expected they all immediately pass out. By next morning, with the bag safe on your side, you reach Ithaca safe and sound!

Secret Good End 2

rooms.title: Curiosity kills your chances of going home, oops
rooms.description: Although you noticed your crew being restless, you presume this to just being their excitement at finally arrived home. Unbeknownst to you, some of your crew have secretly taken the bag underneath your midst and just as you are about to reach land, they are unable to resist their curiosity any longer and the roaring winds immediately blast your ships back to the Aeolian island. You are dumbfounded at the stupidity of your crew, and you sadly walk to Aeolus's home and seek to ask for help again. Unfortunately he recognizes you to have earned the ire of gods and refuses to help anymore, sending you on your way without any wind to help. You must continue your journey unaided.

rooms.title: Island hopping
rooms.description: With no winds to aid you in your journey, you men must tirelessly row

rooms.title: Temples don't have great security
rooms.description:
Turns out, priestesses don't have much in terms to offer in protection and other areas. By morning a wave of Circonians arrive and slaughter your men, including you. Whoops.

Perhaps leaving was the better option?

DEAD END

rooms.title: Leave, but not without some goodies
rooms.description:
Trusting your brain and not your desires, you decide not to stay. The priestess does give you some wine instead as thanks. Regardless, you go about warning your men to leave the city before morning comes, but they hear none of it believing themselves to be superior to all who dare challenge them. You can do nothing to convince them.

Your fears are realized when morning comes and reinforcements called by the scream of the citizens arrive, and your men finally getting the message retreat to the ship, but not without losing some men on the way.

While you sail away from the city, a great storm wracked with lightning, blows you off course for what seems like an eternity to parts of land unknown.
